title: Multiple Bugs in api.data.gov/signup endpoint leads to send custom messages to Anyone

profile.name: TTS Bug Bounty
profile.about: The First Civilian Agency Public Bug Bounty Program

vulnerability_information:
Hey there,

while signing for new api key, i have found two bugs that is unusual and make anyone to send crafted or customised email to someone.

Bug 1: - low 

1. Go to https://api.data.gov/signup/
2. Enter first and last name , then enter email id and get api key.

_Bug: You can use the same email id and signup endlessly._


Bug 2: - Medium/High

1. Go to https://api.data.gov/signup/
2. Enter first and last name , email and sigup
3. Now using Burp Suite Intercept the Proxy.The actual data in POST method looks like the following.


*POST /api-umbrella/v1/users.json?api_key=8Mndjk7k8ygsU4rM1lwBltMzet1FEAIuZeaqzEqV HTTP/1.1
Host: api.data.gov
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.13; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
*Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://api.data.gov/signup/
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
Content-Length: 497
DNT: 1
Connection: close*

*user%5Bfirst_name%5D=tester&user%5Blast_name%5D=moving&user%5Bemail%5D=testermoving%40gmail.com&user%5Buse_description%5D=&user%5Bterms_and_conditions%5D=1&user%5Bregistration_source%5D=web&options%5Bexample_api_url%5D=https%3A%2F%2Fdeveloper.nrel.gov%2Fapi%2Falt-fuel-stations%2Fv1%2Fnearest.json%3Fapi_key%3D%7B%7Bapi_key%7D%7D%26location%3DDenver%2BCO&options%5Bcontact_url%5D=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.data.gov%2Fcontact%2F&options%5Bsite_name%5D=&options%5Bsend_welcome_email%5D=true&options%5Bemail_from_name%5D=&options%5Bemail_from_address%5D=&options%5Bverify_email%5D=true*


4.Now change following parameters as per your choice and send misleading information and phising website from noreply@api.data.gov 

**user%5Bfirst_name%5D = Any sentence you want**
**options%5Bexample_api_url%5D = your phishing site**
**options%5Bcontact_url%5D = your contact URL**

Send the Request to the server and you will receive a crafted message and URL that leads anyone to visit unwanted website. 

**Example:**

Here is my payload that is used to send unintended website URLs and messages which not involved in YOUR DESING. *(you can use the same payload and receive crafted messages and url)*

user%5Bfirst_name%5D=This is from some governemt, Visit the follwing URL to register.&user%5Blast_name%5D=secondname&user%5Bemail%5D=testermoving%40gmail.com&user%5Buse_description%5D=&user%5Bterms_and_conditions%5D=1&user%5Bregistration_source%5D=web&options%5Bexample_api_url%5D=spoofed.websiteO&options%5Bcontact_url%5D=attackercontact.com&options%5Bsite_name%5D=&options%5Bsend_welcome_email%5D=true&options%5Bemail_from_name%5D=&options%5Bemail_from_address%5D=&options%5Bverify_email%5D=true

{F303584}

## Impact

Bug 1 impact:
Acquiring multiple API keys with same email id which is unusual.

Bug 2 impact:
Send Customised message.
Main problem here is, email is received from noreply@api.data.gov which is identified as authentic E-Mail.
Change the _**example URL**_ and make anyone to visit malicious website.
Change _**contact us**_ website.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey there,

while signing for new api key, i have found two bugs that is unusual and make anyone to send crafted or customised email to someone.

Bug 1: - low

  1. Go to https://api.data.gov/signup/
  2. Enter first and last name , then enter email id and get api key.

Bug: You can use the same email id and signup endlessly.

Bug 2: - Medium/High

  1. Go to https://api.data.gov/signup/
  2. Enter first and last name , email and sigup
  3. Now using Burp Suite Intercept the Proxy.The actual data in POST method looks like the following.

POST /api-umbrella/v1/users.json?api_key=8Mndjk7k8ygsU4rM1lwBltMzet1FEAIuZeaqzEqV HTTP/1.1
Host: api.data.gov
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.13; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */; q=0.01
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://api.data.gov/signup/
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
Content-Length: 497
DNT: 1
Connection: close

user%5Bfirst_name%5D=tester&user%5Blast_name%5D=moving&user%5Bemail%5D=testermoving%40gmail.com&user%5Buse_description%5D=&user%5Bterms_and_conditions%5D=1&user%5Bregistration_source%5D=web&options%5Bexample_api_url%5D=https%3A%2F%2Fdeveloper.nrel.gov%2Fapi%2Falt-fuel-stations%2Fv1%2Fnearest.json%3Fapi_key%3D%7B%7Bapi_key%7D%7D%26location%3DDenver%2BCO&options%5Bcontact_url%5D=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.data.gov%2Fcontact%2F&options%5Bsite_name%5D=&options%5Bsend_welcome_email%5D=true&options%5Bemail_from_name%5D=&options%5Bemail_from_address%5D=&options%5Bverify_email%5D=true

4.Now change following parameters as per your choice and send misleading information and phising website from noreply@api.data.gov

user%5Bfirst_name%5D = Any sentence you want
options%5Bexample_api_url%5D = your phishing site
options%5Bcontact_url%5D = your contact URL

Send the Request to the server and you will receive a crafted message and URL that leads anyone to visit unwanted website.

Example:

Here is my payload that is used to send unintended website URLs and messages which not involved in YOUR DESING. (you can use the same payload and receive crafted messages and url)

user%5Bfirst_name%5D=This is from some governemt, Visit the follwing URL to register.&user%5Blast_name%5D=secondname&user%5Bemail%5D=testermoving%40gmail.com&user%5Buse_description%5D=&user%5Bterms_and_conditions%5D=1&user%5Bregistration_source%5D=web&options%5Bexample_api_url%5D=spoofed.websiteO&options%5Bcontact_url%5D=attackercontact.com&options%5Bsite_name%5D=&options%5Bsend_welcome_email%5D=true&options%5Bemail_from_name%5D=&options%5Bemail_from_address%5D=&options%5Bverify_email%5D=true

Impact

Bug 1 impact:
Acquiring multiple API keys with same email id which is unusual.

Bug 2 impact:
Send Customised message.
Main problem here is, email is received from noreply@api.data.gov which is identified as authentic E-Mail.
Change the example URL and make anyone to visit malicious website.
Change contact us website.

activities.message: We appreciate the information and will consider this in the future, but are not taking immediate action at this time as a result of this report and not tracking this as a security issue. Therefore, we'll be closing this report. Thanks and we're looking forward to working with you on future reports.

Therefore, we'll be closing this report. Thanks and we're looking forward to working with you on future reports.

activities.message:
Hey there,

This is totally unexpected. But still with due respect to the team please read the full reply.

Bug 2,  I consider it is a security impact. If not please let me know why.

@thefrog , if this is not a security bug, please accept the following terms.

**1. I would like to use this POC in my upcoming presentation to demonstrate.**
**2. I would like to add this to my blog post and also your reply as "_We appreciate the information and will consider this in the future, but are not taking immediate action at this time as a result of this report and not tracking this as a security issue._"**
**3. If this bug is not even considered as a __informative__ even after important parameters like __CONTACT US__ is modified , make sure this bug will  not be resolved without my knowledge**
**4. I would like continue fuzzing for modifying other parameters which is basically unused and can be used to add further message which can be send to anyone**

Kind Regards,
@nuke11

activities.message:
Sorry for the delay in responding, but thanks for the report!

For item #1, this is working as intended. Users can signup for multiple API keys.

For item #2, this is also working as intended (although it's perhaps not perfectly ideal). This feature was implemented to allow agencies using the api.data.gov service to tailor the example URL and contact URL for their own signup experiences. When we implemented this, we had decided that allowing arbitrary customization of these 2 URLs was acceptable since the full example URL is printed in the message (so users would see the URL they're visiting, although the same isn't necessarily true for the "contact us" link), and the majority of the message body could not be customized, so this couldn't be used for crafting completely arbitrary messages from our e-mail address.

We will discuss item #2 with the team in more detail, though. While we had originally decided that the current behavior was acceptable and this is working as intended, there is room for improvement here, so we'll discuss how we want to handle this and get back to you.
activities.markdown_message:
Sorry for the delay in responding, but thanks for the report!

For item #1, this is working as intended. Users can signup for multiple API keys.

For item #2, this is also working as intended (although it's perhaps not perfectly ideal). This feature was implemented to allow agencies using the api.data.gov service to tailor the example URL and contact URL for their own signup experiences. When we implemented this, we had decided that allowing arbitrary customization of these 2 URLs was acceptable since the full example URL is printed in the message (so users would see the URL they're visiting, although the same isn't necessarily true for the "contact us" link), and the majority of the message body could not be customized, so this couldn't be used for crafting completely arbitrary messages from our e-mail address.

We will discuss item #2 with the team in more detail, though. While we had originally decided that the current behavior was acceptable and this is working as intended, there is room for improvement here, so we'll discuss how we want to handle this and get back to you.

activities.message:
Thanks for the reply, and the full explanation.

1. Problem here is customisation of email template.Even though it is not fully modified, I believe this will be a major problem, when out of 10 at least 2 people redirected to  any website.

2. When contact us URL is basically in HREF TAG, users cannot see them, this is a main problem here.

3. I would like to work on this if you give me permission, if not, there is no problem i could wait until your next response.

4. "**there is room for improvement here**" If this is not a bug and resolved, still anyone could use send messages from your domain.
I strongly believe this is a major problem in your design. I hope this could be solved. 

Yes, i will accept the team response and decision in future.

Thanks,
@gui.

activities.message:
@nuke11: Sorry for the delays on this (yet again). I believe a fix for this should now be deployed, if you'd like to verify.

Details on the fix: For compatibility reasons, we're still accepting the `example_api_url` and `contact_url` options in this API, but we're now sanitizing these URLs to ensure they only point to known domains that are registered and managed within our system. Longer term, we may look to remove these options altogether from the API and provide admins a different way for managing these custom URLs, but I believe the current solution of sanitizing the domains against our known list should also mitigate this.

You can view the code changes involved in this fix here: https://github.com/NREL/api-umbrella/commit/89f7ec277fcca795932a1bfb2116913d5ec84a10

Let us know if you have any questions or feedback, and thanks again for reporting the issue and your patience!
activities.markdown_message:
@nuke11: Sorry for the delays on this (yet again). I believe a fix for this should now be deployed, if you'd like to verify.

Details on the fix: For compatibility reasons, we're still accepting the example_api_url and contact_url options in this API, but we're now sanitizing these URLs to ensure they only point to known domains that are registered and managed within our system. Longer term, we may look to remove these options altogether from the API and provide admins a different way for managing these custom URLs, but I believe the current solution of sanitizing the domains against our known list should also mitigate this.

You can view the code changes involved in this fix here: https://github.com/NREL/api-umbrella/commit/89f7ec277fcca795932a1bfb2116913d5ec84a10

Let us know if you have any questions or feedback, and thanks again for reporting the issue and your patience!
